module.p: dual birthright, hereditary right, inheritance is a masculine noun, with genitive singular duail and plural duail or dualan.

Pedagogical examples –
Bu dual dha sin.
That was to be expected of him (him being the man he is). You would expect that of his people. td. 157
Bu dual dha bàrdachd bho thaobh athar.
He inherited a talent for poetry from his father’s side of the family. td. 157
MacGriogair à Ruadhshruth dam bu dual bhith ’n Gleann Lìobhann ...
MacGregor of Roro whose birthright it was to be in Glen Lyon ... td. 157
bu dual a bhith seinn
born to sing td. 246
Bu dual do dh’isean an ròin a dhol air a thòin chun na mara.
Some people have sea water in their veins ie. take to the sea naturally. td. 246

Pedagogical examples –
mar as dual
as is common/customary td. 246
mar bu dual (dha)
as you would expect (of him), naturally, as was customery (with him) td. 246
Tha iad, mar bu dual, nas lìonmhoire anns na bailtean.
They are, naturally, more abundant in the towns. td. 246
... mar bu dual do na seann Hiortaich
... as was customary to the old St Kildans td. 246

cf. mar bha dual –
Mar bha dual bha mòran dhaoine òga a’ tadhal oirre.
Naturally / as one would expect there were many young men visiting her. td. 246
dualach inherent, hereditary, innate, natural, in one’s nature/temperament is an adjective derived from the noun dual with the suffix -(e)ach. An alternative form is dualtach.

Pedagogical examples –
Tha e dualtach dhut a bhith ag innse bhreugan!
It’s in your nature / just like you / typical of you / to tell lies! td. 157
Tha iad dualach a bhith spìocach.
They are inclined to be stingy/mean. td. 157
Chan eil e dualach don leithid beatha shocrach a mhealtainn
It isn’t usual for the likes of him to enjoy a comfortable life. td. 246
gach tinneas a bhitheas dualach do dhuine
every ailment which is hereditary to man td. 246
Tha e dualtach do iomadh buidheann a bhith ag iarraidh cuideachadh aig an ain àm.
Many groups are liable to be seeking help at the same time. td. 247

dualchas heritage, tradition, character, inheritance, disposition, patrimony is a masculine noun, derived from the adjective dualach with suffix -(e)as, with genitive singular dualchais. An alternative form is dualachas.

Pedagogical examples –
Is e a dhualchas a bhith àrdanach.
It’s in his character/nature to be proud. td. 157
Thèid dualchas an agaidh nan creag.
Heritage will out. td. 247 proverb
... a’ tarraing às an tobar seo de dhualchas
... drawing from this well-spring of tradition td. 247
Thèid duine ri (a) dhualchas seachd uairean anns an latha.
A man shows his heredity seven times a day. td. 247 proverb
Dualchas Nàdair na h-Alba Scottish Natural Heritage is an ergonymic name-description.
dualchasach traditional is an adjective, derived from the noun dualchas with suffix -(e)ach.

Pedagogical examples –
ceòl dualchasach
traditional music td. 157
dualchainnt dialect, brogue is a feminine compound noun, created from the nouns dual and cainnt fem. speech. It has genitive singular dualchainnte and plural dualchainntean.
dual-fhine caste is a feminine compound noun, created from the nouns dual and fine fem. clan, race, tribe. It has genitive singular dual-fhine and plural dual-fhineachan.
Derived from the Old Gaelic masculine noun dúal that which belongs or is proper to an individual by nature or descent, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰewgʰ- hit, produce, be strong.
There is another, independent sense of the noun dual curl/lock/ringlet of hair, plait, strand.
cuir an dualan/duail braid, put into braids.

Pedagogical examples –
Bha ceò a’ tighinn na dhualan dubha bhon luidhear.
Smoke was issuing from the chimney in black curls. td. 246 [Eilidh Watt]
Bha a falt a’ tuiteam na dhuail air a ghuailnean.
Her hair was falling in curls upon her shoulders. td. 246
dualaich curl, twist, plait, braid; typify is a verb derived from the noun dual with suffix -(a)ich, and with verbal noun dualachadh
dualachadh curling, twisting, plaiting is a masculine noun derived from the verb dualaich, with genitive singular dualachaidh.
Derived from the Old Gaelic masculine noun dúal lock or tress as of hair, flax; a plait or fold, from Proto-Indo-European *doḱlos.
